block-definition.comment: For you to fill out! The following is simply starter code.
This is a game board which is expected to be square.
This creates a new empty board of n by n tiles
This is just like the ITEM OF block, but for our game board. You don't need to know how it works.
This is just like the REPLACE block, but for our game board. You don't need to know how it works.
This returns a new distinct copy of the input board which will help prevent you from accidentally reseting list items.

block.comment: Glad to see you're exploring! Here's a question: Why is using "map" here an abstraction violation?

block-definition.comment: The block reports the score of an individual tile.

This block takes in a function and two "sets" of items. The first are the INPUTS to the function. These must be a list whos length is equal to the number of inputs in the function. The OUTPUTS should be the same type as the output of the function. There must be the same number of inputs and outputs.

block.l: ERROR: The number of tests must be the same for inputs and outputs.

block-definition.comment: Returns a list of locations in board which are empty. The locations are length 2 lists as [row, col].
LABEL will stamp text on the stage at the given font size. The direction of the text is the direction the sprite is facing, and color will match the pen color.
block-definition.translations: de:drucke _ in Größe _ ca:etiqueta _ de mida _ es:etiqueta _ de tamaño _ fr:étiquette _ d'une taille de _

block.l: var stage = this.parentThatIsA(StageMorph), context = stage.penTrails().getContext('2d'), rotation = radians(this.direction() - 90), trans = new Point( this.center().x - stage.left(), this.center().y - stage.top() ), isWarped = this.Warped, len, pos; if (isWarped) {endWarp(); } context.save(); context.font = size + 'px monospace'; context.textAlign = 'left'; context.textBaseline = 'alphabetic'; context.fillStyle = this.color.toString(); len = context.measureText(text).width; trans = trans.multiplyBy(1 / stage.scale); context.translate(trans.x, trans.y); context.rotate(rotation); context.fillText(text, 0, 0); context.translate(-trans.x, -trans.y); context.restore(); pos = new Point( len * Math.sin(radians(this.direction())), len * Math.cos(radians(this.direction()))); pos = pos.add(new Point(this.xPosition(), this.yPosition())); this.gotoXY(pos.x, pos.y, false); this.changed(); if (isWarped) {this.startWarp(); } stage.changed();

block-definition.comment: Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) until condition is true, where the three input slots are condition, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f or condition to indicate how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado da invocação em cascata até que _ de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada fins _ _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Returns the function x↦f(g(x)) where f and g are the two inputs.

The inputs are a starting value and one or more monadic functions. The first function is called with the starting value as its input. The second function is called with the value reported by the first function as its input, and so on. PIPE reports the value reported by the last function. PIPE provides an alternative notation for function composition instead of the usual nesting. nested acronym: report (combine (keep items (capital-letter? ( )) from (map (letter (1) of ( )) over (sentence→list (phrase)))) using (join ( ) ( ))) piped acronym: report (pipe (phrase) → (sentence→list ( )) (map (letter (1) of ( )) over ( )) (keep items (capital-letter? ( )) from ( )) (combine ( ) using (join ( ) ( ))) Some people find PIPE easier to read because the functions are called in the same order in which you read them, whereas in nested composition the innermost function is called first.

ZIP takes any number of lists as inputs. The lists should all be the same length. ZIP reports a list of lists in which the first item is a list of all the first items, the second item is a list of all the second items, etc. Viewing the inputs as the rows of a matrix, ZIP reports its transpose.
The identity function reports its input.

Takes as input a function of N inputs and N lists. The function is called with item 1 of all the lists as its inputs, with item 2 of all the lists as its inputs, and so on. (The lists should all be the same length.)
Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) n times where the three input slots are n, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f to represent how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado de _ invocações em cascata de _ com argumento inicial _ _

block-definition.comment: test cases is a list of true/false values. It's 0.5 points for each true value, with a max of 4

list.l: add 2 or 4 ONLY adds to empty slots
add 2 or 4 adds 2 75% of the time
add 2 or 4 adds 4 25% of the time

block.comment: You do not need to modify or understand this script! This simply allows you to use regions of the stage to control the board movement. Try it on a mobile device!
These are simple wrappers to share to with the touch controls above.
This is simply a background. You don't need to do anything in this sprite.

scripts.comment: Testing some of our helper functions to remind you how to use the testing blocks.
You don't need to change ANYTHING in this sprite! If you correctly fill out the functions listed under "2048 - Your Blocks", the game will work.

block.comment: This is a tester sprite, where you put your test cases in for credit.

custom-block.comment: These are your graded test cases! For four out of five of the required blocks, you must have 2 different sets of input and expected output. This means you should have a total of 8 tests below, 2 for each block you test. (You are more than welcome to add as many tests as you like, and add them for additional blocks, as long as you meet the requirements above.) We strongly recommend that you write tests BEFORE starting to write each block!!

scripts.comment: When you are done with testing the four blocks above (hopefully they all return a list of "true" values), drag the four "test" blocks into the four append slots and click this block to set the global variable so that the Autograder script will see that you have at least 8 "true" values, and can give you credit.
BJC CS10 Project 3: 2048 Your job is to fill in the five blocks below; when they are all correct, the game should play exactly as described in the project specification.

We've removed the tests from this sprite; the project specification should explain what each of the five blocks do. You need to create at least two tests for the bottom four blocks and put them in the TESTER sprite. (You don't have to write tests for the "add 2 or 4 to __" block, since that has randomness, and is much harder to test using our deterministic testing framework).

EXAMPLES: These tester blocks take in a reporter -- something that you want to test. The inputs are what you would want to pass into the reporter as a test. The output is what you expect the reporter to output when passed in the input(s). The block will report a Boolean based on whether your test passed. Note: You must leave the inputs to the block you are testing empty.

custom-block.comment: For you to run! This test should fail, since 2 + 4 does not equal 5.
This tests whether 5 - 2 = 3, which should report true.
This tests that new boards are created with the right size.

block.comment: This test ensures that the item of block correctly reports the items at locations (1, 4) and (1, 2)

scripts.comment: From lab: fill in two of your own tests for the "merge column up" block. Refer to our tests of "item of" and "+" above to remember how to deal with "merge column up" needing multiple inputs.
From lab: Fill in what the output should be for the following test case for "merge up". In Project 1, you'll add more of your own "merge up" test cases.
